title: 1373-E
statement: E. Sum of Digitstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLet $$$f(x)$$$ be the sum of digits of a decimal number $$$x$$$.Find the smallest non-negative integer $$$x$$$ such that $$$f(x) + f(x + 1) + \\dots + f(x + k) = n$$$.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 150$$$) â€” the number of test cases.Each test case consists of one line containing two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 150$$$, $$$0 \\le k \\le 9$$$).OutputFor each test case, print one integer without leading zeroes. If there is no such $$$x$$$ that $$$f(x) + f(x + 1) + \\dots + f(x + k) = n$$$, print $$$-1$$$; otherwise, print the minimum $$$x$$$ meeting that constraint.ExampleInput7 1 0 1 1 42 7 13 7 99 1 99 0 99 2Output1 0 4 -1 599998 99999999999 7997

processed.result:
Given a positive integer $n$ and a non-negative integer $k$, find the smallest non-negative integer $x$ such that the sum of the sums of digits of $x$, $x+1$, ..., $x+k$ equals $n$. If no such $x$ exists, print $-1$.

For example:

* If $n=1$ and $k=0$, the answer is $1$ because $f(1)=1$.
* If $n=42$ and $k=7$, the answer is $599998$ because $f(599998) + f(599999) + ... + f(600004) = 42$.
Given a target number and a range, find the smallest number that, when added to the next k numbers, results in a sum of digits equal to the target. If no such number exists, output -1.
